title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: context ANOVA-like tests, common report ANOVA-like effect sizes. effect sizes represent amount variance explained model’s terms, term can represented 1 parameters. example, following case, parameters treatment term represent specific contrasts factor’s levels (treatment groups) - difference level reference level (obk.long == 'control'). can also ask overall effect treatment - much variation dependent variable value can predicted (explained ) variation treatment groups. question can answered ANOVA test: can see, variance value (sums--squares, SS) split pieces: part associated treatment. unexplained part (Residual-SS). can now ask percent total variance value associated treatment. measure called Eta-squared (written \(\eta^2\)): \[ \eta^2 = \frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{total}} = \frac{72.23}{72.23 + 250.96} = 0.22 \] can accessed via eta_squared() function:
code: data(obk.long, package = "afex") # modify the data slightly for the demonstration: obk.long <- obk.long[1:240 %% 3 == 0, ] obk.long$id <- seq_len(nrow(obk.long))  m <- lm(value ~ treatment, data = obk.long)  parameters::model_parameters(m) > Parameter     | Coefficient |   SE |       95% CI | t(77) |      p > ------------------------------------------------------------------ > (Intercept)   |        4.28 | 0.36 | [3.56, 5.00] | 11.85 | < .001 > treatment [A] |        1.97 | 0.54 | [0.89, 3.05] |  3.64 | < .001 > treatment [B] |        2.09 | 0.47 | [1.15, 3.03] |  4.42 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p-values (two-tailed) computed >   using a Wald t-distribution approximation. parameters::model_parameters(anova(m)) > Parameter | Sum_Squares | df | Mean_Square |     F |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------- > treatment |       72.23 |  2 |       36.11 | 11.08 | < .001 > Residuals |      250.96 | 77 |        3.26 |       |        >  > Anova Table (Type 1 tests) library(effectsize) options(es.use_symbols = TRUE) # get nice symbols when printing! (On Windows, requires R >= 4.2.0)   eta_squared(m, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter |   η² |       95% CI > ------------------------------- > treatment | 0.22 | [0.09, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: add terms model, can ask two different questions percent variance explained predictor - much variance accounted predictor total, much accounted controlling predictors. latter questions answered partial-Eta squared (\(\eta^2_p\)), percent partial variance (accounting predictors model) associated term: \[ \eta^2_p = \frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{effect} + SS_{error}} \] can also accessed via eta_squared() function: (phase repeated-measures variable, simplicity modeled .) calculation , SSs computed sequentially - SS phase computed controlling gender, SS treatment computed controlling gender phase. method sequential SS called also type-test. want, ’s great - however many fields (statistical programs) common use “simultaneous” sums squares (type-II type-III tests), SS computed controlling predictors, regardless order. can done car::Anova(type = ...): \(\eta^2_p\) always larger \(\eta^2\). idea simulate effect size design term interest manipulated. terminology assumes causal relationship predictor outcome, reflects experimental world analyses measures hail; However, \(\eta^2_p\) can also simply seen signal--noise- ratio, uses term’s SS error-term’s SS.[^repeated-measure designs term-specific residual-SS used computation effect size]. (Note one-way fixed-effect designs \(\eta^2 = \eta^2_p\).)
code: m <- lm(value ~ gender + phase + treatment, data = obk.long)  eta_squared(m, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter |       η² |       95% CI > ----------------------------------- > gender    |     0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     | 9.48e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |     0.25 | [0.11, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(m) # partial = TRUE by default > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter | η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > gender    |         0.04 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     |         0.01 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |         0.26 | [0.12, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m, type = 2), partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type II) >  > Parameter |       η² |       95% CI > ----------------------------------- > gender    |     0.05 | [0.00, 1.00] > phase     | 9.22e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |     0.24 | [0.11, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m, type = 3)) # partial = TRUE by default > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > gender    |         0.07 | [0.01, 1.00] > phase     |         0.01 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |         0.26 | [0.12, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: Type II type III treat interaction differently. Without going weeds , keep mind using type III SS, important center predictors; numeric variables can done mean-centering predictors; factors can done using orthogonal coding (contr.sum effects-coding) dummy variables (treatment coding, default R). unfortunately makes parameter interpretation harder, SSs associated lower-order term (lower-order interaction) represent SS main effect (treatment coding represent SS simple effects). type-III-effects-coding seems like hassle, can use afex package, takes care behind scenes:
code: # compare m_interaction1 <- lm(value ~ treatment * gender, data = obk.long)  # to: m_interaction2 <- lm(   value ~ treatment * gender,   data = obk.long,   contrasts = list(     treatment = "contr.sum",     gender = "contr.sum"   ) )  eta_squared(car::Anova(m_interaction1, type = 3)) > Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates >   are mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such >   as those produced by `contr.sum`, `contr.poly`, or `contr.helmert`, but >   *not* by the default `contr.treatment`). > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | η² (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------- > treatment        |         0.12 | [0.02, 1.00] > gender           |     9.11e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment:gender |         0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(car::Anova(m_interaction2, type = 3)) > Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates >   are mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such >   as those produced by `contr.sum`, `contr.poly`, or `contr.helmert`, but >   *not* by the default `contr.treatment`). > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | η² (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------- > treatment        |         0.27 | [0.13, 1.00] > gender           |         0.12 | [0.03, 1.00] > treatment:gender |         0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. library(afex) > Loading required package: lme4 > Loading required package: Matrix > ************ > Welcome to afex. For support visit: http://afex.singmann.science/ > - Functions for ANOVAs: aov_car(), aov_ez(), and aov_4() > - Methods for calculating p-values with mixed(): 'S', 'KR', 'LRT', and 'PB' > - 'afex_aov' and 'mixed' objects can be passed to emmeans() for follow-up tests > - NEWS: emmeans() for ANOVA models now uses model = 'multivariate' as default. > - Get and set global package options with: afex_options() > - Set orthogonal sum-to-zero contrasts globally: set_sum_contrasts() > - For example analyses see: browseVignettes("afex") > ************ >  > Attaching package: 'afex' > The following object is masked _by_ '.GlobalEnv': >  >     obk.long > The following object is masked from 'package:lme4': >  >     lmer m_afex <- aov_car(value ~ treatment * gender + Error(id), data = obk.long) > Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment, gender eta_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | η² (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------- > treatment        |         0.27 | [0.13, 1.00] > gender           |         0.12 | [0.03, 1.00] > treatment:gender |         0.20 | [0.07, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: effect sizes unbiased estimators population’s \(\eta^2\): Omega Squared (\(\omega^2\)) Epsilon Squared (\(\epsilon^2\)), also referred Adjusted Eta Squared. \(\omega^2\) \(\epsilon^2\) (partial counterparts, \(\omega^2_p\) & \(\epsilon^2_p\)) unbiased estimators population’s \(\eta^2\) (\(\eta^2_p\), respectively), especially important small samples. Though \(\omega^2\) popular choice (Albers Lakens 2018), \(\epsilon^2\) analogous adjusted-\(R^2\) (Allen 2017, 382), found less biased (Carroll Nordholm 1975).
code: omega_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | ω² (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------- > treatment        |         0.24 | [0.10, 1.00] > gender           |         0.10 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |         0.17 | [0.05, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | ε² (partial) |       95% CI > ---------------------------------------------- > treatment        |         0.25 | [0.11, 1.00] > gender           |         0.11 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |         0.18 | [0.06, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: Partial Eta squared aims estimating effect size design term interest manipulated, assuming terms also manipulated. However, predictors always manipulated - can observed. cases, can use generalized Eta squared (\(\eta^2_G\)), like \(\eta^2_p\) estimating effect size design term interest manipulated, accounting fact terms manipulated (variance present design). \(\eta^2_G\) useful repeated-measures designs, can estimate within-subject effect size predictor manipulated -subjects (Olejnik Algina 2003).
code: eta_squared(m_afex, generalized = "gender") > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | η² (generalized) |       95% CI > -------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |             0.21 | [0.08, 1.00] > gender           |             0.10 | [0.02, 1.00] > treatment:gender |             0.18 | [0.06, 1.00] >  > - Observed variables: gender > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: Finally, forgotten child - Cohen’s \(f\). Cohen’s \(f\) transformation \(\eta^2_p\), ratio term-SS error-SS. \[\text{Cohen's} f_p = \sqrt{\frac{\eta^2_p}{1-\eta^2_p}} = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{effect}}{SS_{error}}}\] can take values zero, population means equal, indefinitely large number means apart. analogous Cohen’s \(d\) two groups.
code: cohens_f(m_afex) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter        | Cohen's f (partial) |      95% CI > ---------------------------------------------------- > treatment        |                0.61 | [0.38, Inf] > gender           |                0.37 | [0.17, Inf] > treatment:gender |                0.50 | [0.28, Inf] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].

what: When Sum-of-Squares are Hard to Come By

text: now ’ve discusses effect sizes fixed-effect linear model repeated-measures ANOVA’s - cases SSs readily available, various effect sized presented can easily estimated. ever always case. example, linear mixed models (LMM/HLM/MLM), estimation required SSs straightforward. However, can still approximate effect sizes (partial versions) based test-statistic approximation method (learn Effect Size Test Statistics vignette). directly `eta_squared() co.: Another case SSs available using Bayesian models…
code: library(lmerTest) >  > Attaching package: 'lmerTest' > The following object is masked from 'package:lme4': >  >     lmer > The following object is masked from 'package:stats': >  >     step fit_lmm <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject), sleepstudy)  anova(fit_lmm) # note the type-3 errors > Type III Analysis of Variance Table with Satterthwaite's method >      Sum Sq Mean Sq NumDF DenDF F value  Pr(>F)     > Days  30031   30031     1    17    45.9 3.3e-06 *** > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 F_to_eta2(45.8, df = 1, df_error = 17) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.73         | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > Days      |         0.73 | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | ε² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > Days      |         0.71 | [0.48, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(fit_lmm) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | ω² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > Days      |         0.70 | [0.47, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: alternative route obtaining effect sizes explained variance, via use posterior predictive distribution (PPD). PPD Bayesian expected distribution possible unobserved values. Thus, observing data, can estimate just expected mean values (conditional marginal means), also full distribution data around values (Gelman et al. 2014, chap. 7). sampling PPD, can decompose sample various SSs needed computation explained variance measures. repeatedly sampling PPD, can generate posterior distribution explained variance estimates. note estimates conditioned location-parameters model, also scale-parameters model! vital validate PPD using estimate explained variance measures. Let’s fit model: can use eta_squared_posterior() get posterior distribution \(eta^2\) \(eta^2_p\) effect. Like ANOVA table, must make sure use right effects-coding SS-type: Compare :
code: library(rstanarm) > Loading required package: Rcpp > This is rstanarm version 2.21.3 > - See https://mc-stan.org/rstanarm/articles/priors for changes to default priors! > - Default priors may change, so it's safest to specify priors, even if equivalent to the defaults. > - For execution on a local, multicore CPU with excess RAM we recommend calling >   options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()) m_bayes <- stan_glm(value ~ gender + phase + treatment,   data = obk.long, family = gaussian(),   refresh = 0 ) pes_posterior <- eta_squared_posterior(m_bayes,   draws = 500, # how many samples from the PPD?   partial = TRUE, # partial eta squared   # type 3 SS   ss_function = car::Anova, type = 3,   verbose = FALSE )  head(pes_posterior) >   gender  phase treatment > 1  0.194 0.1694     0.065 > 2  0.260 0.0268     0.248 > 3  0.004 0.0161     0.186 > 4  0.149 0.1023     0.392 > 5  0.014 0.1156     0.406 > 6  0.025 0.0097     0.364 bayestestR::describe_posterior(pes_posterior,   rope_range = c(0, 0.1), test = "rope" ) > Summary of Posterior Distribution >  > Parameter | Median |       95% CI |         ROPE | % in ROPE > ------------------------------------------------------------ > gender    |   0.07 | [0.00, 0.27] | [0.00, 0.10] |    64.56% > phase     |   0.05 | [0.00, 0.20] | [0.00, 0.10] |    83.54% > treatment |   0.26 | [0.04, 0.47] | [0.00, 0.10] |     7.17% m_ML <- lm(value ~ gender + phase + treatment, data = obk.long)  eta_squared(car::Anova(m_ML, type = 3)) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) >  > Parameter | η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------- > gender    |         0.07 | [0.01, 1.00] > phase     |         0.01 | [0.00, 1.00] > treatment |         0.26 | [0.12, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Sizes for ANOVAs
text: outcome numeric variable, effect sizes described used - measured based sum--squares ill suited outcomes. Instead, must use effect sizes ordinal ANOVAs. R, two functions running ordinal one way ANOVAs: kruskal.test() differences independent groups, friedman.test() differences dependent groups. one-way ordinal ANOVA, Rank-Epsilon-Squared (\(E^2_R\)) Rank-Eta-Squared (\(\eta^2_H\)) measures association similar non-rank counterparts: values range 0 (relative superiority groups) 1 (complete separation - overlap ranks groups). ordinal repeated measures one-way ANOVA, Kendall’s W measure agreement effect condition various “blocks” (subjects), often conceptualized measure reliability rating / scores observations (“groups”) “raters” (“blocks”).
code: group_data <- list(   g1 = c(2.9, 3.0, 2.5, 2.6, 3.2), # normal subjects   g2 = c(3.8, 2.7, 4.0, 2.4), # with obstructive airway disease   g3 = c(2.8, 3.4, 3.7, 2.2, 2.0) # with asbestosis )  kruskal.test(group_data) >  >   Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test >  > data:  group_data > Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 0.8, df = 2, p-value = 0.7 rank_epsilon_squared(group_data) > ε²(R) |       95% CI > -------------------- > 0.06  | [0.02, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. rank_eta_squared(group_data) > η²(H) |       95% CI > -------------------- > 0.13  | [0.08, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. # Subjects are COLUMNS (ReactionTimes <- matrix(   c(     398, 338, 520,     325, 388, 555,     393, 363, 561,     367, 433, 470,     286, 492, 536,     362, 475, 496,     253, 334, 610   ),   nrow = 7, byrow = TRUE,   dimnames = list(     paste0("Subject", 1:7),     c("Congruent", "Neutral", "Incongruent")   ) )) >          Congruent Neutral Incongruent > Subject1       398     338         520 > Subject2       325     388         555 > Subject3       393     363         561 > Subject4       367     433         470 > Subject5       286     492         536 > Subject6       362     475         496 > Subject7       253     334         610 friedman.test(ReactionTimes) >  >   Friedman rank sum test >  > data:  ReactionTimes > Friedman chi-squared = 11, df = 2, p-value = 0.004 kendalls_w(ReactionTimes) > Kendall's W |       95% CI > -------------------------- > 0.80        | [0.76, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Converting Between Probabilities, Odds (Ratios), and Risk Ratios
text: Odds ratio probability complement: \[ Odds = \frac{p}{1-p} \] \[ p = \frac{Odds}{Odds + 1} \] Say bookies gives odds Doutelle win horse race 13:4, probability Doutelle’s win? Manually, can compute \(\frac{13}{13+4}=0.765\). can Odds 13:4 can expressed \((13/4):(4/4)=3.25:1\), can convert: take bet?
code: library(effectsize)  odds_to_probs(13 / 4) > [1] 0.765 # or odds_to_probs(3.25) > [1] 0.765 # convert back probs_to_odds(0.764) > [1] 3.24

title: Converting Between Probabilities, Odds (Ratios), and Risk Ratios
text: Note logistic regression, non-intercept coefficients represent (log) odds ratios, odds. \[ = \frac{Odds_1}{Odds_2} = \frac{\frac{p_1}{1-p_1}}{\frac{p_2}{1-p_2}} \] intercept, however, represent (log) odds, variables fixed 0.

what: Converting Odds ratios to Risk Ratios
title: Converting Between Probabilities, Odds (Ratios), and Risk Ratios
text: Odds ratio, although popular, intuitive interpretations. don’t often think chances catching disease terms odds, instead instead tend think terms probability event - risk. Talking risks can also talk change risk, knows risk ratio (RR). example, find individual suffering migraine, every bowl brussels sprouts eat, ’re odds reducing migraine increase \(= 3.5\) period hour. , people eat brussels sprouts effectively reduce pain? Well, hard say… Maybe look RR ’ll get clue. can convert RR following formula (Grant 2014): \[ RR = \frac{}{(1 - p0 + (p0 \times ))}   \] \(p0\) base-rate risk - probability event without intervention (e.g., probability migraine subsiding within hour without eating brussels sprouts). base-rate risk , say, 85%, get RR : - every bowl brussels sprouts, increase chances reducing migraine mere 12%! worth ? Depends affinity brussels sprouts… Note base-rate risk crucial . instead 85% 4%, RR : - every bowl brussels sprouts, increase chances reducing migraine whopping 318%! worth ? guess still depends affinity brussels sprouts…
code: OR <- 3.5 baserate <- 0.85  oddsratio_to_riskratio(OR, baserate) > [1] 1.12 OR <- 3.5 baserate <- 0.04  oddsratio_to_riskratio(OR, baserate) > [1] 3.18

title: Converting Between r, d, and Odds Ratios
text: basic conversion r values, measure standardized association two continuous measures, d values (Cohen’s d), measure standardized differences two groups / conditions. Let’s looks (simulated) data: can compute Cohen’s d two groups: can also compute point-biserial correlation, Pearson’s r treating 2-level is_senior variable numeric binary variable: summary statistics? Say, \(d=-0.72\) want know r ? can approximate r using following formula (Borenstein et al. 2009): \[ r \approx \frac{d}{\sqrt{d^2 + 4}} \] indeed, use d_to_r(), get pretty decent approximation: (also works way, r_to_d(0.12) gives 0.723) can see, rough approximations, can useful don’t raw data hand.
code: library(effectsize) data("hardlyworking") head(hardlyworking) >   salary xtra_hours n_comps age seniority is_senior > 1  19745       4.16       1  32         3     FALSE > 2  11302       1.62       0  34         3     FALSE > 3  20636       1.19       3  33         5      TRUE > 4  23047       7.19       1  35         3     FALSE > 5  27342      11.26       0  33         4     FALSE > 6  25657       3.63       2  30         5      TRUE cohens_d(salary ~ is_senior, data = hardlyworking) > Cohen's d |         95% CI > -------------------------- > -0.72     | [-0.90, -0.53] >  > - Estimated using pooled SD. correlation::cor_test(hardlyworking, "salary", "is_senior") > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |    r |       95% CI | t(498) |         p > ------------------------------------------------------------------ > salary     |  is_senior | 0.34 | [0.26, 0.41] |   7.95 | < .001*** >  > Observations: 500 d_to_r(-0.72) > [1] -0.339

title: Converting Between r, d, and Odds Ratios

code: fit <- lm(salary ~ is_senior + xtra_hours, data = hardlyworking)  parameters::model_parameters(fit) > Parameter     | Coefficient |     SE |               95% CI | t(497) |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)   |    14258.87 | 238.71 | [13789.86, 14727.87] |  59.73 | < .001 > is seniorTRUE |     1683.65 | 316.85 | [ 1061.12,  2306.17] |   5.31 | < .001 > xtra hours    |     1257.75 |  40.33 | [ 1178.51,  1336.99] |  31.19 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p-values (two-tailed) computed >   using a Wald t-distribution approximation. # A couple of ways to get partial-d: 1683.65 / sigma(fit) > [1] 0.495 t_to_d(5.31, df_error = 497)[[1]] > [1] 0.476 t_to_r(5.31, df_error = 497) > r    |       95% CI > ------------------- > 0.23 | [0.15, 0.31] correlation::correlation(hardlyworking[, c("salary", "xtra_hours", "is_senior")],   include_factors = TRUE,   partial = TRUE )[2, ] > # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) >  > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |    r |       95% CI | t(498) |         p > ------------------------------------------------------------------ > salary     |  is_senior | 0.23 | [0.15, 0.31] |   5.32 | < .001*** >  > p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) > Observations: 500 # all close to: d_to_r(0.47) > [1] 0.229

title: Converting Between r, d, and Odds Ratios
text: binomial regression (specifically logistic regression), Odds ratios () measures effect size; indicate expected change odds event. fields, common dichotomize outcomes order able analyze logistic models. example, outcome count white blood cells, can useful (medically) predict crossing threshold rather raw count . , scientists maybe analyze data t-test present Cohen’s d, others might analyze logistic regression model dichotomized outcome, present . question can asked: given , Cohen’s d ? Fortunately, formula approximate (Sánchez-Meca, Marı́n-Martı́nez, Chacón-Moscoso 2003): \[ d = log() \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\pi} \] implemented oddsratio_to_d() function. Let’s give try:
code: # 1. Set a threshold thresh <- 22500  # 2. dichotomize the outcome hardlyworking$salary_high <- hardlyworking$salary < thresh  # 3. Fit a logistic regression: fit <- glm(salary_high ~ is_senior,   data = hardlyworking,   family = binomial() )  parameters::model_parameters(fit) > Parameter     | Log-Odds |   SE |         95% CI |     z |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept)   |     1.55 | 0.16 | [ 1.25,  1.87] |  9.86 | < .001 > is seniorTRUE |    -1.22 | 0.21 | [-1.63, -0.82] | -5.86 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (profile-likelihood) and p-values (two-tailed) >   computed using a Wald z-distribution approximation. >  > The model has a log- or logit-link. Consider using `exponentiate = TRUE` >   to interpret coefficients as ratios. # Convert log(OR) (the coefficient) to d oddsratio_to_d(-1.22, log = TRUE) > [1] -0.673

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: theoretical applied research, often interest assess strength observed association. typically done allow judgment magnitude effect [especially units measurement meaningful, e.g., use estimated latent variables; Bollen (1989)], facilitate comparing predictors’ importance within given model, . Though indices effect size, correlation coefficient (standardized covariance coefficient) readily available, measures often harder obtain. effectsize R package (R Core Team 2020) fills important gap, providing utilities easily estimating wide variety standardized effect sizes (.e., effect sizes tied units measurement variables interest) confidence intervals (CIs), variety statistical models. effectsize provides easy--use functions, full documentation explanation various effect sizes offered, also used developers R packages back-end effect size computation, parameters (Lüdecke et al. 2020), ggstatsplot (Patil 2018), gtsummary (Sjoberg et al. 2020) .

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: effectsize’s functionality part comparable packages like lm.beta (Behrendt 2014), MOTE (Buchanan et al. 2019), MBESS (K. Kelley 2020). Yet, notable differences, e.g.: MOTE MBESS provide functions computing effect sizes Cohen’s d effect sizes ANOVAs (Cohen 1988), confidence intervals. However, require manual input F- t-statistics, degrees freedom, sums squares computation effect sizes, whereas effectsize can automatically extract information provided models, thus allowing better ease--use well reducing potential error.

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: Note: functionality moved parameters datawizard packages. Standardizing parameters (.e., coefficients) can allow comparison within models, variables studies. end, two functions available: standardize(), returns updated model, re-fit standardized data, standardize_parameters(), returns table standardized coefficients provided model [list supported models, see insight package; Lüdecke, Waggoner, Makowski (2019)]. Standardized parameters can also produced generalized linear models (GLMs; predictors standardized): standardize_parameters() provides several standardization methods, robust standardization, pseudo-standardized coefficients (generalized) linear mixed models (Hoffman 2015). full review methods can found Parameter Model Standardization vignette.
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ cyl * am,   data = mtcars )  datawizard::standardize(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = mpg ~ cyl * am, data = data_std) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)          cyl           am       cyl:am   #>     -0.0977      -0.7426       0.1739      -0.1930  parameters::standardize_parameters(model) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Std. Coef. |         95% CI #> ----------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |      -0.10 | [-0.30,  0.11] #> cyl         |      -0.74 | [-0.95, -0.53] #> am          |       0.17 | [-0.04,  0.39] #> cyl:am      |      -0.19 | [-0.41,  0.02] model <- glm(am ~ cyl + hp,   family = "binomial",   data = mtcars )  parameters::standardize_parameters(model, exponentiate = TRUE) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter   | Std_Odds_Ratio |        95% CI #> -------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept) |           0.53 | [0.18,  1.32] #> cyl         |           0.05 | [0.00,  0.29] #> hp          |           6.70 | [1.32, 61.54] #>  #> - Response is unstandardized.

title: Effect Sizes: Getting Started
text: Unlike standardized parameters, effect sizes reported context ANOVAs (analysis variance) ANOVA-like tables represent amount variance explained model’s terms, term can represented one parameters. eta_squared() can produce popular effect sizes Eta-squared (\(\eta^2\)), partial version (\(\eta^2_p\)), well generalized \(\eta^2_G\) (Cohen 1988; Olejnik Algina 2003): effectsize also offers \(\epsilon^2_p\) (epsilon_squared()) \(\omega^2_p\) (omega_squared()), less biased estimates variance explained population (T. L. Kelley 1935; Olejnik Algina 2003). details various effect size measures applications, see Effect sizes ANOVAs vignette.
code: options(contrasts = c("contr.sum", "contr.poly"))  data("ChickWeight") # keep only complete cases and convert `Time` to a factor ChickWeight <- subset(ChickWeight, ave(weight, Chick, FUN = length) == 12) ChickWeight$Time <- factor(ChickWeight$Time)  model <- aov(weight ~ Diet * Time + Error(Chick / Time),   data = ChickWeight )  eta_squared(model, partial = TRUE) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Group      | Parameter | η² (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------- #> Chick      |      Diet |         0.27 | [0.06, 1.00] #> Chick:Time |      Time |         0.87 | [0.85, 1.00] #> Chick:Time | Diet:Time |         0.22 | [0.11, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  eta_squared(model, generalized = "Time") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Group      | Parameter | η² (generalized) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------------- #> Chick      |      Diet |             0.04 | [0.00, 1.00] #> Chick:Time |      Time |             0.74 | [0.71, 1.00] #> Chick:Time | Diet:Time |             0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Observed variables: Time #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Support Functions for Model Extensions
text: input data frame must columns: - Parameter (char) - name parameter , often, term. - Sum_Squares (num) - sum squares. - df (num) - degrees freedom associated Sum_Squares. - Mean_Square_residuals (num; optional) - present, calculated Sum_Squares / df. (column ignored.) exactly 1 row Parameter Residual. Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) value Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass data frame .es_aov_simple(): output data frame columns: Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: generalized, ci, alternative, anova_type (NA NULL), approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output.
code: min_aov <- data.frame(   Parameter = c("(Intercept)", "A", "B", "Residuals"),   Sum_Squares = c(30, 40, 10, 100),   df = c(1, 1, 2, 50) ) .es_aov_simple(   min_aov,   type = "eta", partial = TRUE, generalized = FALSE,   include_intercept = FALSE,   ci = 0.95, alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE ) >   Parameter Eta2_partial   CI CI_low CI_high > 1         A        0.286 0.95   0.12       1 > 2         B        0.091 0.95   0.00       1

title: Support Functions for Model Extensions
text: (e.g., aovlist models.) input data frame must columns: Group (char) - strata Parameter (char) Sum_Squares (num) df (num) Mean_Square_residuals (num; optional) exactly 1 row per Group Parameter Residual. Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) value Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass data frame .es_aov_strata(), along list predictors (including stratifying variables) DV_names argument: output data frame columns: Group, Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: generalized, ci, alternative, approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output.
code: min_aovlist <- data.frame(   Group = c("S", "S", "S:A", "S:A"),   Parameter = c("(Intercept)", "Residuals", "A", "Residuals"),   Sum_Squares = c(34, 21, 34, 400),   df = c(1, 12, 4, 30) ) .es_aov_strata(   min_aovlist,   DV_names = c("S", "A"),   type = "omega", partial = TRUE, generalized = FALSE,   ci = 0.95, alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE,   include_intercept = TRUE ) >   Group   Parameter Omega2_partial   CI CI_low CI_high > 1     S (Intercept)           0.57 0.95   0.21       1 > 2   S:A           A           0.00 0.95   0.00       1

title: Support Functions for Model Extensions

(Can also t col instead, case df set 1, F t^2). df_error (num) - error degrees freedom. Optionally, one rows can (Intercept) Parameter. example minimally valid data frame: Pass table .es_aov_table(): output data frame columns: Parameter, effect size, (optionally) CI + CI_low + CI_high, following attributes: generalized, ci, alternative, approximate. can set anova_type attribute {1, 2, 3, NA} return output, optionally approximate attribute, return output.
code: min_anova <- data.frame(   Parameter = c("(Intercept)", "A", "B"),   F = c(4, 7, 0.7),   df = c(1, 1, 2),   df_error = 34 ) .es_aov_table(   min_anova,   type = "eta", partial = TRUE, generalized = FALSE,   include_intercept = FALSE,   ci = 0.95, alternative = "greater",   verbose = TRUE ) >   Parameter Eta2_partial   CI CI_low CI_high > 1         A         0.17 0.95  0.023       1 > 2         B         0.04 0.95  0.000       1

title: Support Functions for Model Extensions
text: Let’s fit simple linear model change class: now need new .anova_es.superMODEL function: … ’s ! new superMODEL class models fully supported!
code: mod <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) + am, mtcars)  class(mod) <- "superMODEL" .anova_es.superMODEL <- function(model, ...) {   # Get ANOVA table   anov <- suppressWarnings(stats:::anova.lm(model))   anov <- as.data.frame(anov)    # Clean up   anov[["Parameter"]] <- rownames(anov)   colnames(anov)[2:1] <- c("Sum_Squares", "df")    # Pass   out <- .es_aov_simple(anov, ...)    # Set attribute   attr(out, "anova_type") <- 1    out } eta_squared(mod) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI > ------------------------------------------- > factor(cyl) |           0.76 | [0.61, 1.00] > am          |           0.12 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(mod, partial = FALSE) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Eta2 |       95% CI > --------------------------------- > factor(cyl) | 0.73 | [0.57, 1.00] > am          | 0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. omega_squared(mod) > # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) >  > Parameter   | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------------------------- > factor(cyl) |             0.73 | [0.56, 1.00] > am          |             0.08 | [0.00, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. # Etc...

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: many real world applications straightforward ways obtaining standardized effect sizes. However, possible get approximations effect size indices (\(d\), \(r\), \(\eta^2_p\)…) use test statistics. conversions based idea test statistics function effect size sample size. Thus information samples size (often degrees freedom) used reverse-engineer indices effect size test statistics. idea functions also power Effect Sizes Test Statistics shiny app. measures discussed , one way another, signal noise ratios, “noise” representing unaccounted variance outcome variable1. indices : Percent variance explained (\(\eta^2_p\), \(\omega^2_p\), \(\epsilon^2_p\)). Measure association (\(r\)). Measure difference (\(d\)).

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: measures represent ratio \(Signal^2 / (Signal^2 + Noise^2)\), “noise” “signals” partial-ed (fixed random effects). popular indices \(\eta^2_p\) (Eta; equivalent \(R^2\)). conversion \(F\)- \(t\)-statistic based Friedman (1982). Let’s look example: Let’s compare \(\eta^2_p\) (pes column) obtained ones recovered F_to_eta2(): identical!2 (except fact F_to_eta2() also provides confidence intervals3 :) case able easily obtain effect size (thanks afex!), cases might easy, using estimates based test statistic offers good approximation. example:
code: library(afex)  data(md_12.1)  aov_fit <- aov_car(rt ~ angle * noise + Error(id / (angle * noise)),   data = md_12.1,   anova_table = list(correction = "none", es = "pes") ) aov_fit > Anova Table (Type 3 tests) >  > Response: rt >        Effect    df     MSE         F  pes p.value > 1       angle 2, 18 3560.00 40.72 *** .819   <.001 > 2       noise  1, 9 8460.00 33.77 *** .790   <.001 > 3 angle:noise 2, 18 1160.00 45.31 *** .834   <.001 > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '+' 0.1 ' ' 1 library(effectsize) options(es.use_symbols = TRUE) # get nice symbols when printing! (On Windows, requires R >= 4.2.0)  F_to_eta2(   f = c(40.72, 33.77, 45.31),   df = c(2, 1, 2),   df_error = c(18, 9, 18) ) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.82         | [0.66, 1.00] > 0.79         | [0.49, 1.00] > 0.83         | [0.69, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: can also use t_to_eta2() contrast analysis:
code: library(emmeans)  joint_tests(aov_fit, by = "noise") > noise = absent: >  model term df1 df2 F.ratio p.value >  angle        2   9   8.000  0.0096 >  > noise = present: >  model term df1 df2 F.ratio p.value >  angle        2   9  51.000  <.0001 F_to_eta2(   f = c(5, 79),   df = 2,   df_error = 29 ) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.26         | [0.04, 1.00] > 0.84         | [0.75, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. pairs(emmeans(aov_fit, ~angle)) >  contrast estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value >  X0 - X4      -108 17.4  9  -6.200  0.0004 >  X0 - X8      -168 20.6  9  -8.200  0.0001 >  X4 - X8       -60 18.4  9  -3.300  0.0244 >  > Results are averaged over the levels of: noise  > P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 3 estimates t_to_eta2(   t = c(-6.2, -8.2, -3.3),   df_error = 9 ) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.81         | [0.54, 1.00] > 0.88         | [0.70, 1.00] > 0.55         | [0.13, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: can also use t_to_eta2() slope Days (case gives result).
code: library(lmerTest)  fit_lmm <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (Days | Subject), sleepstudy)  anova(fit_lmm) > Type III Analysis of Variance Table with Satterthwaite's method >      Sum Sq Mean Sq NumDF DenDF F value  Pr(>F)     > Days  30031   30031     1    17    45.9 3.3e-06 *** > --- > Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 F_to_eta2(45.8, 1, 17) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.73         | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. parameters::model_parameters(fit_lmm, effects = "fixed", ci_method = "satterthwaite") > # Fixed Effects >  > Parameter   | Coefficient |   SE |           95% CI | t(17.00) |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |      251.41 | 6.82 | [237.01, 265.80] |    36.84 | < .001 > Days        |       10.47 | 1.55 | [  7.21,  13.73] |     6.77 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p-values (two-tailed) computed >   using a Wald t-distribution with Satterthwaite approximation. t_to_eta2(6.77, df_error = 17) > η² (partial) |       95% CI > --------------------------- > 0.73         | [0.51, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: Alongside \(\eta^2_p\) also less biased \(\omega_p^2\) (Omega) \(\epsilon^2_p\) (Epsilon; sometimes called \(\text{Adj. }\eta^2_p\), equivalent \(R^2_{adj}\); Albers Lakens (2018), Mordkoff (2019)).

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: Similar \(\eta^2_p\), \(r\) signal noise ratio, fact equal \(\sqrt{\eta^2_p}\) (’s really partial \(r\)). often used instead \(\eta^2_p\) discussing strength association (suspect people use instead \(\eta^2_p\) gives bigger number, looks better).

title: Effect Size from Test Statistics
text: fixed-effect linear model, returns partial correlation. Compare: :
code: parameters::model_parameters(fit_lmm, effects = "fixed", ci_method = "satterthwaite") > # Fixed Effects >  > Parameter   | Coefficient |   SE |           95% CI | t(17.00) |      p > ----------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |      251.41 | 6.82 | [237.01, 265.80] |    36.84 | < .001 > Days        |       10.47 | 1.55 | [  7.21,  13.73] |     6.77 | < .001 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p-values (two-tailed) computed >   using a Wald t-distribution with Satterthwaite approximation. t_to_r(6.77, df_error = 17) > r    |       95% CI > ------------------- > 0.85 | [0.67, 0.92] fit_lm <- lm(rating ~ complaints + critical, data = attitude)  parameters::model_parameters(fit_lm) > Parameter   | Coefficient |    SE |         95% CI | t(27) |      p > ------------------------------------------------------------------- > (Intercept) |       14.25 | 11.17 | [-8.67, 37.18] |  1.28 | 0.213  > complaints  |        0.75 |  0.10 | [ 0.55,  0.96] |  7.46 | < .001 > critical    |    1.91e-03 |  0.14 | [-0.28,  0.28] |  0.01 | 0.989 >  > Uncertainty intervals (equal-tailed) and p-values (two-tailed) computed >   using a Wald t-distribution approximation. t_to_r(   t = c(7.46, 0.01),   df_error = 27 ) > r        |        95% CI > ------------------------ > 0.82     | [ 0.67, 0.89] > 1.92e-03 | [-0.35, 0.35] correlation::correlation(attitude,  select = "rating",  select2 = c("complaints", "critical"),  partial = TRUE ) > # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) >  > Parameter1 | Parameter2 |        r |        95% CI | t(28) |         p > ---------------------------------------------------------------------- > rating     | complaints |     0.82 | [ 0.65, 0.91] |  7.60 | < .001*** > rating     |   critical | 2.70e-03 | [-0.36, 0.36] |  0.01 | 0.989     >  > p-value adjustment method: Holm (1979) > Observations: 30

code: pairs(emmeans(aov_fit, ~angle)) >  contrast estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value >  X0 - X4      -108 17.4  9  -6.200  0.0004 >  X0 - X8      -168 20.6  9  -8.200  0.0001 >  X4 - X8       -60 18.4  9  -3.300  0.0244 >  > Results are averaged over the levels of: noise  > P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 3 estimates t_to_r(   t = c(-5.7, -8.9, -3.2),   df_error = 18 ) > r     |         95% CI > ---------------------- > -0.80 | [-0.89, -0.57] > -0.90 | [-0.95, -0.78] > -0.60 | [-0.79, -0.22]

title: Effect Sizes for Contingency Tables
text: larger contingency tables, Cramér’s V, Tschuprow’s T, Cohen’s w, Pearson’s C can used. Cramér’s V Tschuprow’s T true measures correlation: range 0 1, 0 indicating complete independence nominal variables, 1 indicating complete dependence. square tables, equal, however non-square tables \(T < V\); Cramér’s V defines complete dependence “possible know exactly value columns rows know exactly value rows columns”, Tschuprow’s T required true achieve complete dependence - something possible non-square tables. example: case, know food product, know vegan , knowing food vegan always let know food product . Cohen’s w Pearson’s C true measures correlation, two types normalized \(\chi^2\) values. Pearson’s C capped 1, Cohen’s w can larger 1 (, 0 indicates association variables). (Cramer’s V, Tschuprow’s T, Cohen’s w can also used 2--2 tables, equivalent \(\phi\).)
code: data("food_class") food_class >           Soy Milk Meat > Vegan      47    0    0 > Not-Vegan   0   12   21 cramers_v(food_class, adjust = FALSE) > Cramer's V |       95% CI > ------------------------- > 1.00       | [0.81, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. tschuprows_t(food_class) > Tschuprow's T |       95% CI > ---------------------------- > 0.84          | [0.68, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. data("Music_preferences2") Music_preferences2 >       Pop Rock Jazz Classic > Psych 151  130   12       7 > Econ   77    6  111       4 > Law     0    4    2     165 chisq.test(Music_preferences2) >  >   Pearson's Chi-squared test >  > data:  Music_preferences2 > X-squared = 854, df = 6, p-value <2e-16 cramers_v(Music_preferences2) > Cramer's V (adj.) |       95% CI > -------------------------------- > 0.80              | [0.75, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. tschuprows_t(Music_preferences2) > Tschuprow's T |       95% CI > ---------------------------- > 0.72          | [0.68, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. pearsons_c(Music_preferences2) > Pearson's C |       95% CI > -------------------------- > 0.75        | [0.73, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. cohens_w(Music_preferences2) # > 1 > Cohen's w |       95% CI > ------------------------ > 1.13      | [1.06, 1.41] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.41~].

title: Effect Sizes for Contingency Tables
text: 2--2 tables, can also compute Odds-ratio (), column represents different group. Values larger 1 indicate odds higher first group (vice versa). can also compute Risk-ratio (RR), ratio proportions two groups - measure claim intuitive. Additionally, Cohen’s h can also computed, uses arcsin transformation. Negative values indicate smaller proportion first group (vice versa).
code: data("RCT_table") RCT_table >            Group > Diagnosis   Treatment Control >   Sick             71      30 >   Recovered        50     100 chisq.test(RCT_table) # or fisher.test(RCT_table) >  >   Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction >  > data:  RCT_table > X-squared = 32, df = 1, p-value = 2e-08 oddsratio(RCT_table) > Odds ratio |       95% CI > ------------------------- > 4.73       | [2.74, 8.17] riskratio(RCT_table) > Risk ratio |       95% CI > ------------------------- > 2.54       | [1.87, 3.45] cohens_h(RCT_table) > Cohen's h |       95% CI > ------------------------ > 0.74      | [0.50, 0.99]

title: Effect Sizes for Contingency Tables
text: Bayesian estimate effect sizes can also provided based BayesFactor’s version \(\chi^2\)-test via effectsize() function:
code: BFX <- contingencyTableBF(RCT_table, sampleType = "jointMulti")  effectsize(BFX, type = "or") > Odds ratio |       95% CI > ------------------------- > 4.63       | [2.71, 8.08] effectsize(BFX, type = "rr") > Risk ratio |       95% CI > ------------------------- > 2.48       | [1.82, 3.59] effectsize(BFX, type = "cohens_h") > Cohen's h |       95% CI > ------------------------ > 0.74      | [0.49, 0.98]

title: Effect Sizes for Contingency Tables
text: dependent (paired) contingency tables, Cohen’s g represents symmetry table, ranging 0 (perfect symmetry) 0.5 (perfect asymmetry). example, two tests seem equally predictive disease screening: mean give number positive/negative results? Test 1 gives positive results test 2!
code: data("screening_test")  phi(screening_test$Diagnosis, screening_test$Test1) > ϕ (adj.) |       95% CI > ----------------------- > 0.85     | [0.81, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. phi(screening_test$Diagnosis, screening_test$Test2) > ϕ (adj.) |       95% CI > ----------------------- > 0.85     | [0.81, 1.00] >  > - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. tests <- table(Test1 = screening_test$Test1, Test2 = screening_test$Test2) tests >        Test2 > Test1   "Neg" "Pos" >   "Neg"   794    86 >   "Pos"   150   570 mcnemar.test(tests) >  >   McNemar's Chi-squared test with continuity correction >  > data:  tests > McNemar's chi-squared = 17, df = 1, p-value = 4e-05 cohens_g(tests) > Cohen's g |       95% CI > ------------------------ > 0.14      | [0.07, 0.19]

title: Convert F and t Statistics to partial-\(\eta^2\) and Other ANOVA Effect Sizes — F_to_eta2
text: functions use following formulae:  $$\eta_p^2 = \frac{F \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den}}$$  $$\epsilon_p^2 = \frac{(F - 1) \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den}}$$  $$\omega_p^2 = \frac{(F - 1) \times df_{num}}{F \times df_{num} + df_{den} + 1}$$  $$f_p = \sqrt{\frac{\eta_p^2}{1-\eta_p^2}}$$  t, conversion based equality \(t^2 = F\) \(df_{num}=1\).

title: Convert F and t Statistics to partial-\(\eta^2\) and Other ANOVA Effect Sizes — F_to_eta2
text: Omega Epsilon unbiased estimators population Eta. choose? Though Omega popular choice, noted : formula given Omega approximation complex designs. Epsilon found less biased (Carroll & Nordholm, 1975).

text: Unless stated otherwise, confidence (compatibility) intervals (CIs) estimated using noncentrality parameter method (also called "pivot method"). method finds noncentrality parameter ("ncp") noncentral t, F, \(\chi^2\) distribution places observed t, F, \(\chi^2\) test statistic desired probability point distribution. example, observed t statistic 2.0, 50 degrees freedom, cumulative noncentral t distribution t = 2.0 .025 quantile (answer: noncentral t distribution ncp = .04)? estimating confidence bounds ncp, converted effect size metric obtain confidence interval effect size (Steiger, 2004).  additional details estimation troubleshooting, see effectsize_CIs.

title: Convert F and t Statistics to partial-\(\eta^2\) and Other ANOVA Effect Sizes — F_to_eta2
text: "Confidence intervals measures effect size convey information hypothesis test, ." (Steiger, 2004). Confidence (compatibility) intervals p values complementary summaries parameter uncertainty given observed data. dichotomous hypothesis test performed either CI p value. 100 (1 - \(\alpha\))% confidence interval contains parameter values p > \(\alpha\) current data model. example, 95% confidence interval contains values p > .05.  Note confidence interval including 0 indicate null (effect) true. Rather, suggests observed data together model assumptions combined provided clear evidence parameter value 0 (value interval), level evidence defined chosen \(\alpha\) level (Rafi & Greenland, 2020; Schweder & Hjort, 2016; Xie & Singh, 2013). infer effect, additional judgments parameter values "close enough" 0 negligible needed ("equivalence testing"; Bauer & Kiesser, 1996).

what: Cohen's d and Other Standardized Differences — cohens_d
title: Cohen's d and Other Standardized Differences — cohens_d
text: Compute effect size indices standardized differences: Cohen's d, Hedges' g Glass’s delta (\(\Delta\)). (function returns population estimate.) Pair reported stats::t.test().  Cohen's d Hedges' g estimated standardized difference means two populations. Hedges' g provides bias correction (using exact method) Cohen's d small sample sizes. sample sizes > 20, results statistics roughly equivalent. Glass’s delta appropriate standard deviations significantly different populations, uses second group's standard deviation.

title: Cohen's d and Other Standardized Differences — cohens_d
code: cohens_d(   x,   y = NULL,   data = NULL,   pooled_sd = TRUE,   mu = 0,   paired = FALSE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "two.sided",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  hedges_g(   x,   y = NULL,   data = NULL,   pooled_sd = TRUE,   mu = 0,   paired = FALSE,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "two.sided",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  glass_delta(   x,   y = NULL,   data = NULL,   mu = 0,   ci = 0.95,   alternative = "two.sided",   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Cohen's d and Other Standardized Differences — cohens_d
text: x, y numeric vector, character name one data. missing values (NAs) dropped resulting vector. x can also formula (see stats::t.test()), case y ignored. data optional data frame containing variables. pooled_sd TRUE (default), sd_pooled() used (assuming equal variance). Else mean SD groups used instead. mu number indicating true value mean (    difference means performing two sample test). paired TRUE, values x y considered paired. produces effect size equivalent one-sample effect size x - y. ci Confidence Interval (CI) level alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis; Controls type CI returned: "two.sided" (default, two-sided CI), "greater" "less" (one-sided CI). Partial matching allowed (e.g., "g", "l", "two"...). See One-Sided CIs effectsize_CIs. verbose Toggle warnings messages . ... Arguments passed methods. x formula, can subset na.action.

Estimated using pooled SD. # Same as: # cohens_d("mpg", "am", data = mtcars) # cohens_d(mtcars$mpg[mtcars$am=="0"], mtcars$mpg[mtcars$am=="1"])  # More options: cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars, pooled_sd = FALSE) #> Cohen's d |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.41     | [-2.26, -0.53] #>  #> - Estimated using un-pooled SD. cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars, mu = -5) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -0.46     | [-1.17, 0.26] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -5. #> - Estimated using pooled SD. cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars, alternative = "less") #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-Inf, -0.80] #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-Inf]. hedges_g(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) #> Hedges' g |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.44     | [-2.21, -0.65] #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. glass_delta(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) #> Glass' delta |         95% CI #> ----------------------------- #> -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39]   # One Sample ----------  cohens_d(wt ~ 1, data = mtcars) #> Cohen's d |       95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 3.29      | [2.40, 4.17]  # same as: # cohens_d("wt", data = mtcars) # cohens_d(mtcars$wt)  # More options: cohens_d(wt ~ 1, data = mtcars, mu = 3) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.22      | [-0.13, 0.57] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of 3. hedges_g(wt ~ 1, data = mtcars, mu = 3) #> Hedges' g |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.22      | [-0.13, 0.56] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of 3.   # Paired Samples ----------  data(sleep)  cohens_d(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep) #> Cohen's d |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.28     | [-2.12, -0.41]  # same as: # cohens_d(sleep$extra[sleep$group == 1], sleep$extra[sleep$group == 2], paired = TRUE)  # More options: cohens_d(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep, mu = -1) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -0.47     | [-1.12, 0.20] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -1. hedges_g(Pair(extra[group == 1], extra[group == 2]) ~ 1, data = sleep) #> Hedges' g |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.17     | [-1.94, -0.38]   # Interpretation ----------------------- interpret_cohens_d(-1.48, rules = "cohen1988") #> [1] "large" #> (Rules: cohen1988) #>  interpret_hedges_g(-1.48, rules = "sawilowsky2009") #> [1] "very large" #> (Rules: sawilowsky2009) #>  interpret_glass_delta(-1.48, rules = "gignac2016") #> [1] "large" #> (Rules: gignac2016) #>  # Or: interpret(d, rules = "sawilowsky2009") #> Cohen's d |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] |     very large #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. #> - Interpretation rule: sawilowsky2009  # Common Language Effect Sizes d_to_u3(1.48) #> [1] 0.9305634 # Or: print(d, append_CLES = TRUE) #> Cohen's d |         95% CI #> -------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. #>  #> ## Common Language Effect Sizes: #> Name            | CLES |       95% CI #> ------------------------------------- #> Pr(superiority) | 0.15 | [0.05, 0.32] #> Cohen's U1      | 0.70 | [0.42, 0.85] #> Cohen's U2      | 0.77 | [0.63, 0.87] #> Cohen's U3      | 0.07 | [0.01, 0.25] #> Overlap         | 0.46 | [0.26, 0.74] # }

title: Effect Size for Paired Contingency Tables — cohens_g
text: "Confidence intervals measures effect size convey information hypothesis test, ." (Steiger, 2004). Confidence (compatibility) intervals p values complementary summaries parameter uncertainty given observed data. dichotomous hypothesis test performed either CI p value. 100 (1 - \(\alpha\))% confidence interval contains parameter values p > \(\alpha\) current data model. example, 95% confidence interval contains values p > .05.  Note confidence interval including 0 indicate null (effect) true. Rather, suggests observed data together model assumptions combined provided clear evidence parameter value 0 (value interval), level evidence defined chosen \(\alpha\) level (Rafi & Greenland, 2020; Schweder & Hjort, 2016; Xie & Singh, 2013). infer effect, additional judgments parameter values "close enough" 0 negligible needed ("equivalence testing"; Bauer & Kiesser, 1996).

title: Convert \(\chi^2\) to \(\phi\) and Other Correlation-like Effect Sizes — chisq_to_phi
text: data frame effect size(s), confidence interval(s). See cramers_v().

title: Convert \(\chi^2\) to \(\phi\) and Other Correlation-like Effect Sizes — chisq_to_phi
text: functions use following formulas: $$\phi = w = \sqrt{\chi^2 / n}$$  $$\textrm{Cramer's } V = \phi / \sqrt{\min(\textit{nrow}, \textit{ncol}) - 1}$$ $$\textrm{Tschuprow's } T = \phi / \sqrt[4]{(\textit{nrow} - 1) \times (\textit{ncol} - 1)}$$ $$פ = \phi / \sqrt{[1 / \min(p_E)] - 1}$$  \(p_E\) expected probabilities. $$\textrm{Pearson's } C = \sqrt{\chi^2 / (\chi^2 + n)}$$ bias-adjusted versions \(\phi\) \(V\), see Bergsma, 2013.

title: Convert \(\chi^2\) to \(\phi\) and Other Correlation-like Effect Sizes — chisq_to_phi
text: Unless stated otherwise, confidence (compatibility) intervals (CIs) estimated using noncentrality parameter method (also called "pivot method"). method finds noncentrality parameter ("ncp") noncentral t, F, \(\chi^2\) distribution places observed t, F, \(\chi^2\) test statistic desired probability point distribution. example, observed t statistic 2.0, 50 degrees freedom, cumulative noncentral t distribution t = 2.0 .025 quantile (answer: noncentral t distribution ncp = .04)? estimating confidence bounds ncp, converted effect size metric obtain confidence interval effect size (Steiger, 2004).  additional details estimation troubleshooting, see effectsize_CIs.

title: Convert Between d, r, and Odds Ratio — d_to_r
text: Converted index.

title: Convert Between d, r, and Odds Ratio — d_to_r
text: Conversions d done formulae: \(d = \frac{\log()\times\sqrt{3}}{\pi}\) \(log() = d * \frac{\pi}{\sqrt(3)}\) Converting d r done formulae: \(d = \frac{\sqrt{h} * r}{\sqrt{1 - r^2}}\) \(r = \frac{d}{\sqrt{d^2 + h}}\) \(h = \frac{n_1 + n_2 - 2}{n_1} + \frac{n_1 + n_2 - 2}{n_2}\). groups equal size, h reduces approximately 4. resulting r also called binomial effect size display (BESD; Rosenthal et al., 1982).

title: Convert Standardized Differences to Common Language Effect Sizes — diff_to_cles
text: function use following formulae Cohen's d: $$Pr(superiority) = \Phi(d/\sqrt{2})$$  $$\textrm{Cohen's } U_3 = \Phi(d)$$  $$\textrm{Cohen's } U_2 = \Phi(|d|/2)$$  $$\textrm{Cohen's } U_1 = (2\times U_2 - 1)/U_2$$  $$Overlap = 2 \times \Phi(-|d|/2)$$  following rank-biserial correlation: $$Pr(superiority) = (r_{rb} + 1)/2$$  \(WMW_{Odds} = Pr(superiority) / (1 - Pr(superiority))\)

what: effectsize: Indices of Effect Size — effectsize-package
title: effectsize: Indices of Effect Size — effectsize-package
text: theoretical applied research, often interest assess strength observed association. typically done allow judgment magnitude effect, especially units measurement meaningful. Though indices effect size, correlation coefficient (standardized covariance coefficient) readily available, measures often harder obtain. effectsize fills important gap, providing utilities easily estimating wide variety standardized effect sizes (.e., effect sizes tied units measurement variables interest) confidence intervals (CIs), variety statistical models hypothesis tests, cohens_d(), phi(), eta_squared(), many . See vignette("effectsize", package = "effectsize") details, vignette(package = "effectsize") full list vignettes. References: Ben-Shachar et al. (2020) doi:10.21105/joss.02815 .

Chi-squared tests independence Fisher's Exact Test, depending type: "cramers_v" (default), "tschuprows_t", "phi", "cohens_w", "pearsons_c", "cohens_h", "oddsratio", "riskratio". Chi-squared tests goodness--fit, depending type: "fei" (default) "cohens_w", "pearsons_c" One-way ANOVA test, depending type: "eta" (default), "omega" "epsilon" -squared, "f", "f2". McNemar test returns Cohen's g. Wilcoxon test depending type: returns "rank_biserial" correlation (default) one "p_superiority", "vda", "u2", "u3", "overlap". Kruskal-Wallis test depending type: "epsilon" (default) "eta". Friedman test returns Kendall's W. (applicable, ci alternative taken htest otherwise provided.) object class BFBayesFactor, using bayestestR::describe_posterior(), t-test depending type: "cohens_d" (default) one "p_superiority", "u1", "u2", "u3", "overlap". correlation test returns r. contingency table test, depending type: "cramers_v" (default), "phi", "tschuprows_t", "cohens_w", "pearsons_c", "cohens_h", "oddsratio", "riskratio". proportion test returns p. Objects class anova, aov, aovlist afex_aov, depending type: "eta" (default), "omega" "epsilon" -squared, "f", "f2". objects passed parameters::standardize_parameters(). statistical models recommended directly use listed functions, full range options provide.

title: Effect Sizes — effectsize.BFBayesFactor
code: ## Hypothesis Testing ## ------------------ data("Music_preferences") Xsq <- chisq.test(Music_preferences) effectsize(Xsq) #> Cramer's V (adj.) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------- #> 0.23              | [0.18, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(Xsq, type = "cohens_w") #> Cohen's w |       95% CI #> ------------------------ #> 0.34      | [0.27, 1.41] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.41~].  Tt <- t.test(1:10, y = c(7:20), alternative = "less") effectsize(Tt) #> Warning: Missing values detected. NAs dropped. #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -2.19     | [-Inf, -1.32] #>  #> - Estimated using un-pooled SD. #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-Inf].  Aov <- oneway.test(extra ~ group, data = sleep, var.equal = TRUE) effectsize(Aov) #> Eta2 |       95% CI #> ------------------- #> 0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(Aov, type = "omega") #> Omega2 |       95% CI #> --------------------- #> 0.11   | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  Wt <- wilcox.test(1:10, 7:20, mu = -3, alternative = "less") #> Warning: cannot compute exact p-value with ties effectsize(Wt) #> Warning: Missing values detected. NAs dropped. #> r (rank biserial) |         95% CI #> ---------------------------------- #> -0.65             | [-1.00, -0.36] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -3. #> - One-sided CIs: lower bound fixed at [-1.00]. effectsize(Wt, type = "u2") #> Warning: Missing values detected. NAs dropped. #> Cohen's U2 |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 0.73       | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Non-parametric CLES  ## Models and Anova Tables ## ----------------------- fit <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + hp, data = mtcars) effectsize(fit) #> # Standardization method: refit #>  #> Parameter                        | Std. Coef. |         95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------------------- #> (Intercept)                      |   1.14e-03 | [-0.53,  0.53] #> factor(cyl)-0.104987808575239    |      -0.20 | [-0.79,  0.38] #> factor(cyl)1.01488214956065      |      -0.32 | [-1.06,  0.42] #> wt                               |      -0.90 | [-1.33, -0.46] #> hp                               |      -0.25 | [-0.52,  0.01] #> factor(cyl)-0.104987808575239:wt |       0.37 | [-0.63,  1.36] #> factor(cyl)1.01488214956065:wt   |       0.54 | [ 0.03,  1.06]  anova_table <- anova(fit) effectsize(anova_table) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter      | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> factor(cyl)    |           0.86 | [0.76, 1.00] #> wt             |           0.47 | [0.22, 1.00] #> hp             |           0.14 | [0.00, 1.00] #> factor(cyl):wt |           0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. effectsize(anova_table, type = "epsilon") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter      | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------- #> factor(cyl)    |               0.85 | [0.74, 1.00] #> wt             |               0.44 | [0.20, 1.00] #> hp             |               0.11 | [0.00, 1.00] #> factor(cyl):wt |               0.09 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00].  ## Bayesian Hypothesis Testing ## --------------------------- # \donttest{ bf_prop <- BayesFactor::proportionBF(3, 7, p = 0.3) effectsize(bf_prop) #> p     |       95% CI #> -------------------- #> 0.367 | [0.16, 0.65]  bf_corr <- BayesFactor::correlationBF(attitude$rating, attitude$complaints) effectsize(bf_corr) #> rho  |       95% CI #> ------------------- #> 0.76 | [0.51, 0.88]  data(RCT_table) bf_xtab <- BayesFactor::contingencyTableBF(RCT_table, sampleType = "poisson", fixedMargin = "cols") effectsize(bf_xtab) #> Cramer's V (adj.) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------- #> 0.35              | [0.23, 0.46] effectsize(bf_xtab, type = "oddsratio") #> Odds ratio |       95% CI #> ------------------------- #> 4.66       | [2.72, 8.22]  bf_ttest <- BayesFactor::ttestBF(sleep$extra[sleep$group == 1],   sleep$extra[sleep$group == 2],   paired = TRUE, mu = -1 ) effectsize(bf_ttest) #> Cohen's d |        95% CI #> ------------------------- #> -0.33     | [-1.01, 0.32] #>  #> - Deviation from a difference of -1. #> - Estimated using pooled SD. # }

code: # \donttest{  data("hardlyworking") model <- aov(salary ~ age + factor(n_comps) * cut(seniority, 3), data = hardlyworking) es <- eta_squared(model, ci = 0.9, alternative = "two.sided") equivalence_test(es, range = 0.15) # TOST #> Warning: Lower bound set to 0.00. #> # Test for Practical Equivalence  #> ROPE: [0.00, 0.15] #>  #> Parameter                         | Eta2 (partial) |       90% CI |       H0 #> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> age                               |           0.16 | [0.12, 0.21] | Rejected #> factor(n_comps)                   |           0.21 | [0.16, 0.26] | Rejected #> cut(seniority, 3)                 |           0.17 | [0.12, 0.21] | Rejected #> factor(n_comps):cut(seniority, 3) |           0.01 | [0.00, 0.03] | Accepted  data("RCT_table") OR <- oddsratio(RCT_table, alternative = "greater") equivalence_test(OR, range = 1) #> # Test for Practical Equivalence  #> ROPE: [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> Odds ratio |      95% CI |       H0 #> ----------------------------------- #> 4.73       | [3.00, Inf] | Rejected #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  ds <- t_to_d(   t = c(0.45, -0.65, 7, -2.2, 2.25),   df_error = c(675, 525, 2000, 900, 1875),   ci = 0.9, alternative = "two.sided" # TOST ) # Can also plot if (require(see)) plot(equivalence_test(ds, range = 0.2))  if (require(see)) plot(equivalence_test(ds, range = 0.2, rule = "cet"))  if (require(see)) plot(equivalence_test(ds, range = 0.2, rule = "bayes"))  # }

One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. epsilon_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |               0.61 | [0.40, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |               0.63 | [0.41, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |               0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. cohens_f(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Cohen's f (partial) |      95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |                1.30 | [0.86, Inf] #> cyl_f      |                1.38 | [0.90, Inf] #> am_f:cyl_f |                0.33 | [0.00, Inf] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  model0 <- aov(mpg ~ am_f + cyl_f, data = mtcars) # no interaction cohens_f_squared(model0, model2 = model) #> Cohen's f2 (partial) |      95% CI | R2_delta #> --------------------------------------------- #> 0.11                 | [0.00, Inf] |     0.02 #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [Inf].  ## Interpretation of effect sizes ## ------------------------------  interpret_omega_squared(0.10, rules = "field2013") #> [1] "medium" #> (Rules: field2013) #>  interpret_eta_squared(0.10, rules = "cohen1992") #> [1] "small" #> (Rules: cohen1992) #>  interpret_epsilon_squared(0.10, rules = "cohen1992") #> [1] "small" #> (Rules: cohen1992) #>   interpret(eta2, rules = "cohen1992") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter  | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ----------------------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |           0.63 | [0.42, 1.00] |          large #> cyl_f      |           0.66 | [0.45, 1.00] |          large #> am_f:cyl_f |           0.10 | [0.00, 1.00] |          small #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: cohen1992  if (FALSE) { # require("see") && FALSE plot(eta2) # Requires the {see} package } # Recommended: Type-2 or -3 effect sizes + effects coding # ------------------------------------------------------- contrasts(mtcars$am_f) <- contr.sum contrasts(mtcars$cyl_f) <- contr.sum  model <- aov(mpg ~ am_f * cyl_f, data = mtcars) model_anova <- car::Anova(model, type = 3)  epsilon_squared(model_anova) #> Type 3 ANOVAs only give sensible and informative results when covariates #>   are mean-centered and factors are coded with orthogonal contrasts (such #>   as those produced by `contr.sum`, `contr.poly`, or `contr.helmert`, but #>   *not* by the default `contr.treatment`). #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter  | Epsilon2 (partial) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------- #> am_f       |               0.08 | [0.00, 1.00] #> cyl_f      |               0.60 | [0.38, 1.00] #> am_f:cyl_f |               0.03 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. # afex takes care of both type-3 effects and effects coding: data(obk.long, package = "afex") model <- afex::aov_car(value ~ treatment * gender + Error(id / (phase)),   data = obk.long, observed = "gender" ) #> Warning: More than one observation per design cell, aggregating data using `fun_aggregate = mean`. #> To turn off this warning, pass `fun_aggregate = mean` explicitly. #> Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment, gender  omega_squared(model) #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Omega2 (partial) |       95% CI #> -------------------------------------------------------- #> treatment              |             0.31 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |             0.18 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |             0.22 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |             0.26 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |             0.15 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |             0.00 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |             0.00 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. eta_squared(model, generalized = TRUE) # observed vars are pulled from the afex model. #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type III) #>  #> Parameter              | Eta2 (generalized) |       95% CI #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> treatment              |               0.25 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender                 |               0.16 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender       |               0.24 | [0.00, 1.00] #> phase                  |               0.20 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:phase        |               0.13 | [0.00, 1.00] #> gender:phase           |           4.25e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] #> treatment:gender:phase |               0.02 | [0.00, 1.00] #>  #> - Observed variables: gender #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. if (FALSE) { # require("lmerTest") && require("lme4") && FALSE ## Approx. effect sizes for mixed models ## ------------------------------------- model <- lme4::lmer(mpg ~ am_f * cyl_f + (1 | vs), data = mtcars) omega_squared(model) } if (FALSE) { # require(rstanarm) && require(bayestestR) && require(car) && FALSE ## Bayesian Models (PPD) ## --------------------- fit_bayes <- rstanarm::stan_glm(   mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + qsec,   data = mtcars, family = gaussian(),   refresh = 0 )  es <- eta_squared_posterior(fit_bayes,   verbose = FALSE,   ss_function = car::Anova, type = 3 ) bayestestR::describe_posterior(es, test = NULL)   # compare to: fit_freq <- lm(mpg ~ factor(cyl) * wt + qsec,   data = mtcars ) aov_table <- car::Anova(fit_freq, type = 3) eta_squared(aov_table) }

code: rules_grid <- rules(c(0.01, 0.05), c("very significant", "significant", "not significant")) interpret(0.001, rules_grid) #> [1] "very significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(0.021, rules_grid) #> [1] "significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(0.08, rules_grid) #> [1] "not significant" #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>  interpret(c(0.01, 0.005, 0.08), rules_grid) #> [1] "very significant" "very significant" "not significant"  #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>   interpret(c(0.35, 0.15), c("small" = 0.2, "large" = 0.4), name = "Cohen's Rules") #> [1] "large" "small" #> (Rules: Cohen's Rules) #>  interpret(c(0.35, 0.15), rules(c(0.2, 0.4), c("small", "medium", "large"))) #> [1] "medium" "small"  #> (Rules: Custom rules) #>   # ---------- d <- cohens_d(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) interpret(d, rules = "cohen1988") #> Cohen's d |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------- #> -1.48     | [-2.27, -0.67] |          large #>  #> - Estimated using pooled SD. #> - Interpretation rule: cohen1988  d <- glass_delta(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars) interpret(d, rules = "gignac2016") #> Glass' delta |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------- #> -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39] |          large #>  #> - Interpretation rule: gignac2016  interpret(d, rules = rules(1, c("tiny", "yeah okay"))) #> Glass' delta |         95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------- #> -1.17        | [-1.93, -0.39] |      yeah okay #>  #> - Interpretation rule: Custom rules  m <- lm(formula = wt ~ am * cyl, data = mtcars) eta2 <- eta_squared(m) interpret(eta2, rules = "field2013") #> # Effect Size for ANOVA (Type I) #>  #> Parameter | Eta2 (partial) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ---------------------------------------------------------- #> am        |           0.63 | [0.44, 1.00] |          large #> cyl       |           0.47 | [0.24, 1.00] |          large #> am:cyl    |       2.26e-03 | [0.00, 1.00] |     very small #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: field2013  X <- chisq.test(mtcars$am, mtcars$cyl == 8) interpret(oddsratio(X), rules = "chen2010") #> Odds ratio |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------ #> 0.11       | [0.02, 0.62] |          large #>  #> - Interpretation rule: chen2010 interpret(cramers_v(X), "lovakov2021") #> Cramer's V (adj.) |       95% CI | Interpretation #> ------------------------------------------------- #> 0.44              | [0.03, 1.00] |          large #>  #> - One-sided CIs: upper bound fixed at [1.00]. #> - Interpretation rule: lovakov2021

text: x vector values, object class lavaan. rules Can "default" custom set rules(). ... Currently used.

title: Interpret of CFA / SEM Indices of Goodness of Fit — interpret_gfi
text: Chisq: model Chi-squared assesses overall fit discrepancy sample fitted covariance matrices. p-value > .05 (.e., hypothesis perfect fit rejected). However, quite sensitive sample size. GFI/AGFI: (Adjusted) Goodness Fit proportion variance accounted estimated population covariance. Analogous R2. GFI AGFI > .95 > .90, respectively. NFI/NNFI/TLI: (Non) Normed Fit Index. NFI 0.95, indicates model interest improves fit 95\ NNFI (also called Tucker Lewis index; TLI) preferable smaller samples. > .90 (Byrne, 1994) > .95 (Schumacker & Lomax, 2004). CFI: Comparative Fit Index revised form NFI. sensitive sample size (Fan, Thompson, & Wang, 1999). Compares fit target model fit independent, null, model. > .90. RMSEA: Root Mean Square Error Approximation parsimony-adjusted index. Values closer 0 represent good fit. < .08 < .05. p-value printed tests hypothesis RMSEA less equal .05 (cutoff sometimes used good fit), thus significant. RMR/SRMR: (Standardized) Root Mean Square Residual represents square-root difference residuals sample covariance matrix hypothesized model. RMR can sometimes hard interpret, better use SRMR. < .08. RFI: Relative Fit Index, also known RHO1, guaranteed vary 0 1. However, RFI close 1 indicates good fit. IFI: Incremental Fit Index (IFI) adjusts Normed Fit Index (NFI) sample size degrees freedom (Bollen's, 1989). 0.90 good fit, index can exceed 1. PNFI: Parsimony-Adjusted Measures Index. commonly agreed-upon cutoff value acceptable model index. > 0.50. See documentation fitmeasures().

title: Interpret of CFA / SEM Indices of Goodness of Fit — interpret_gfi
text: structural equation models (SEM), Kline (2015) suggests minimum following indices reported: model chi-square, RMSEA, CFI SRMR.

title: Interpret of CFA / SEM Indices of Goodness of Fit — interpret_gfi

(1973). reliability coefficient maximum likelihood factor analysis. Psychometrika, 38, 1-10. Schumacker, R. E., Lomax, R. G. (2004). beginner's guide structural equation modeling, Second edition. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. Fan, X., B. Thompson, L. Wang (1999). Effects sample size, estimation method, model specification structural equation modeling fit indexes. what: Mahalanobis' D (a multivariate Cohen's d) — mahalanobis_d
title: Mahalanobis' D (a multivariate Cohen's d) — mahalanobis_d
text: Compute effect size indices standardized difference two normal multivariate distributions one multivariate distribution defined point. standardized effect size Hotelling's \(T^2\) test (e.g., DescTools::HotellingsT2Test()). D computed :  $$D = \sqrt{(\bar{X}_1-\bar{X}_2-\mu)^T \Sigma_p^{-1} (\bar{X}_1-\bar{X}_2-\mu)}$$  \(\bar{X}_i\) column means, \(\Sigma_p\) pooled covariance matrix, \(\mu\) vector null differences variable. one variate, formula reduces Cohen's d.

Can also vector length 1, recycled. ci Confidence Interval (CI) level alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis; Controls type CI returned: "two.sided" (default, two-sided CI), "greater" "less" (one-sided CI).
